Instruction.Newbie:
An information report informs readers about a topic, object, process or issue.

Reports give readers facts and information so that a reader can better understand the topic, object or issue, or to better understand the topic, object or issue from the writer's point of view.
Instruction.Developing:
An information report informs readers about a topic, object, process or issue.

Its purpose is to give readers facts and information so that a reader can better understand a topic, object or issue. Sometimes information reports are written so that a reader can understand a topic or issue from the writer's point of view.

For example, an information report on volcanoes might contain information such as: a definition of a volcano, how volcanos form and how they work, how long volcanos take to form, what they are made of, and a diagram or image.
Instruction.Flying:
An information report informs readers about a topic, object, process or issue.

Its purpose is to give readers facts and information so that a reader can better understand a topic, object or issue. Sometimes information reports are written so that a reader can understand a topic or issue from the writer's point of view.

For example, an information report on volcanoes might contain information such as: a definition of a volcano, how volcanos form and how they work, how long volcanos take to form, what they are made of, and a diagram or image.

An information report on marsupials, such as a kangaroo, might include information on: what defines a marsupial, where marsupials live, what marsupials eat and how marsupials breed.

Instruction.Newbie:
Information reports have a number of key features.

Information reports:

  • contain an introduction paragraph, body paragraphs and a conclusion
  • contain a description or definition of the topic or object
  • are usually organised into key parts with subheadings for each key idea, feature or description
  • are usually written from the 3rd person point of view and are not casual.
Instruction.Developing:
What do information reports look like? What do they contain?

Information reports vary depending on the report's subject matter and its audience. However, there are key features that many information reports share. Information reports:

  • contain an introduction paragraph, body paragraphs and a conclusion
  • contain a description or definition of the topic or object
  • are usually organised into key parts with subheadings for each key idea, feature or description
  • are usually written from the 3rd person point of view and are not casual.
Instruction.Flying:
What are the key generic features of information reports?

Although information reports vary depending on each report's subject matter and audience,information reports usually:

  • contain an introduction paragraph, body paragraphs and a conclusion
  • contain a description or definition of the topic or object
  • are usually organised into key parts with subheadings for each key idea, feature or description
  • are usually written from the 3rd person point of view and are not casual.

Tasks.Title: Purpose

Instruction.Newbie:
Your report must have a purpose, usually to inform. Is it to: describe the key features of an object or process? Explain the causes for a process?

Instruction.Developing:
Your report must have a purpose, usually to inform.

A report may:

  • describe the main features of the topic/object, such as a flower
  • explain how something works, like a volcano or motor
  • explain the causes or origins of something, like hurricanes
  • describe the effects, benefits or disadvantages of the topic, such as poverty
  • and much more.

Tasks.Title: Writing the introduction

Instruction.Newbie:
You now need to put your research into your report. This is your first go, so you can change it at any time.

You will draft your report using:

  • Introduction (introduce your topic)
  • Main paragraphs
  • Conclusion

    A report's introduction is the first paragraph of the report. Your introduction should tell the reader your topic and the main points you will describe.
Instruction.Developing:
You now need to put your research into your report. This is your first go, so you can change it at any time.

You will draft your report using:

  • Introduction (introduce your topic)
  • Main paragraphs
  • Conclusion

    A report's introduction is the first paragraph of the report. Your introduction tells the reader what your essay is about.

    What do you put in your introduction? You should tell the reader your topic and the main points you will describe. It should be brief.

    After you have written your introduction, read it and ask yourself whether a reader would know what your essay is about and what your main ideas are. To help you, you can select the samples icon on the top right corner of the screen.

Tasks.Title: Writing the conclusion

Instruction.Newbie:
Your report should finish with a conclusion.

The conclusion is a paragraph that tells the reader the points you have made. To write your conclusion, you should look over the main points you have made in your report and re-write them in 2 or 3 sentences.
